en.value: Writing about travel experiences - Past simple

If you recently returned from a trip, you are likely to have a few stories to share! We are going to focus on describing positive and negative experiences when travelling. Take a look at the examples:
The view from the hotel was amazing.
The air conditioning didn't work, it was horrible!
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
The food in the hotel restaurant was amazing!
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
The water pressure in the villa was really disappointing.
Match the adjective with its definition.
when something is worse than expected
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
The staff in the hostel laundry service were so helpful!
If someone is "helpful" they are happy to provide others with help and assistance.
The staff in the laundry service did not provide any assistance to guests.
The sunset at the beach was unforgettable.
This was definitely a once-in-a-lifetime trip.
Our kind host was the highlight of the trip for me.
Match the phrase to its meaning.
an experience that you won't forget
The hotel in Chiang Mai was very luxurious.
The air conditioning didn't work all week, it was horrible!
The view from the hotel room was jaw-dropping!
Select the adjectives that describe something positive.
The location of the restaurant was nice but the food was nothing special.
Jack thought that the food at the restaurant was amazing.
The beach was beautiful - the photos really don't do it justice!
to leave much to be desired
The tiny kitchen left much to be desired.
"It was great, the website doesn't do it justice." - Something is better than it appears in photos or online.
"The tiny kitchen <u>left much to be desired</u>." - It was not satisfactory.
Some of the phrases you have just learned are quite complex. Here's a quick recap:
Match the pairs of words / phrases.
So far we have seen a variety of phrases to describe our travels. Let's have a quick look at them again before we practise using them.
The tiny kitchen <u>left much to be desired</u>.
Fill in the gap using the image.
The hotel in Chang Mai was very [k]luxurious[/k]
Select the words in the correct order.
Listen and select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
The view from the hotel room was [k]jaw-dropping[/k]!
How does Anna describe the staff working in the hostel laundry service?
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.
The water pressure in the villa was really di[k]s[/k][k]a[/k][k]p[/k][k]p[/k]ointing.
Select the correct words to fill the gaps.
The location of the restaurant was nice but the food was [k]nothing[/k] [k]special[/k].
Our kind host was the highlight of the trip for me!
Select the words that make this a positive review of a trip.
The beach was [h]amazing[/h] - the photos really [h]don't[/h] [h]do[/h] [h]it[/h] [h]justice[/h]!
The tiny kitchen [k]left[/k] much to be desired.
The sunset at the beach was unfor[k]g[/k][k]e[/k][k]t[/k][k]t[/k]able.
Our kind host was [k]the[/k] [k]highlight[/k] of the trip.
Fill in the gap using the audio.
The sunset at the beach was [k]unforgettable[/k].
The water pressure in the villa was really [k]disappointing[/k].
What does Lena think about her upcoming trip to Australia?
It will be an incredible experience.
She will be able to go lots of times.
The beach was beautiful - the photos really [k]don't do it justice[/k]
Fill in the gap using the hint.
An experience that was not particularly good.
The hotel in Chiang Mai was really [k]luxurious[/k].
The view from the hotel room was [k]jaw-dropping[/k]!

We studied the "past simple" in A2, learning about regular and irregular verbs, negative forms and questions. Now we're in B1, we'll take a closer look at the "past simple", looking at pronunciation, irregular forms and common errors. Let's go!

First, a quick review. We use the "past simple" to talk about a completed action in the past. The action can be recent or from a long time ago, something that happened once or repeatedly, and it doesn't matter how long the action lasted.

Regular verbs in the past simple have the ending -ed [walk → walked, move → moved, study → studied]. With irregular verbs, you have to learn the "past simple" forms one by one [go → went, take → took, make → made].
What did you do last night? I studied English.
We went to the seaside every summer when we were kids.
I took lots of photos on that trip.
I didn't make you a birthday cake this year - I made cookies instead.
Last weekend, I walked into town, went to a cafe and read a book.
This sentence contains a mix of past and present verb forms.
"Walked", "went" and "read" are all "past simple" forms. "Read" is spelled the same way in both its "present simple" and "past simple" forms, but the pronunciation changes.
I read a lot of books. Last week I read a new novel by Haruki Murakami.
Present-simple "read" rhymes with "need"; past-simple "read" rhymes with "bed".
Listen to the audio and select the correct statement.
The speaker is describing actions in the past.
The speaker is describing actions in the present.
The speaker is describing actions in the future.
I listened to music, watched TV and started a new book.
The -ed verb ending is pronounced the same way in these three words: listened, watched and started.
The -ed verb ending is pronounced as /d/ in "listened", as /t/ in "watched" and as /ɪd/ in "started".
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
The island was really beautiful and the beaches [k]were[/k] amazing.
Have you noticed that some verbs have two "past simple" forms? Both forms are correct. The forms ending in -t are especially common in British English.
Select the alternate spelling of the "past simple" form in this sentence: I learned English at school.
Select the missing word in this joke by British comedian Tommy Cooper.
Last night I [k]dreamt[/k] I ate a ten-pound marshmallow. When I woke up the pillow was gone.
I accidentally cut my finger when I put the knives in the dishwasher last night.
This sentence is about events taking place in the present.
This sentence is about past events. Did you know? A few verbs - including "cut", "put", "hit" and "let" - are spelled and pronounced the same way in both the "present simple" and "past simple".
As soon as I got home, I [k]put[/k] the shopping in the fridge.
Did he hurt you? Yeah, he [k]hit[/k] me really hard!
My parents [k]let[/k] me ride my bike to school, but only if I wore a helmet.
Now test your knowledge of the "past simple" with a quiz! Before you start, check out the conjugation table below:
Last weekend, I [k]went[/k] to a cafe and read a book.
I [k]brought[/k] my sunglasses but I forgot my hat.
Select the correct option to complete this sentence: I ______ English when I was little.
Our host, Minh, was great. She [k]led[/k] us from the villa to the nearby shops and restaurants.
We didn't like the hotel at all. The room [k]was[/k] small and the staff [k]were[/k] unhelpful.
Complete the sentence by typing the "past simple" form of the verb "put".
I prepared the desserts and [k]put[/k] them in the fridge.
My sister didn't liked cheese when she was little, but now she does.
The correct sentence is: My sister didn't like cheese when she was little, but now she does.
I [k]went[/k] shopping last weekend and [k]bought[/k] a new coat.
We arrived early but the friendly hotel staff [k]let[/k] us drop our bags in our room.
The correct sentence is: Where did you go?
The hostel only [k]took[/k] cash payments, but fortunately there was an ATM nearby.

In this unit, you are going to read three different reviews left on travel sites about places to stay on vacation. These reviews are taken from popular travel booking websites and represent the type of language you are likely to find online.
Read this first review. What did Josephe89 think of his stay?

User: Josephe89
March 13th, 2019

This was so disappointing! From pics this hotel looked inviting and chill with a cool concept, but the rooms were horrible, our shower had no water pressure, and when you flushed the toilet the shower became boiling hot. Our bathroom was not clean when we arrived and the breakfast area smelled funny. In the morning when we went to get breakfast, they had no more food! Laundry service in the hotel was very expensive, it was much cheaper in town. The room was too hot, and the air conditioning unit was not working. We liked the hammocks, palm trees and cheap bicycles for rent on site.
What did Josephe89 think of his stay?
Match the object to the problem mentioned in the text.
We can use the word "when" to connect two related events. Let's look at how the writer did it in this review:
When you flushed the toilet the shower became boiling hot.
Our bathroom was not clean when we arrived
In the morning when we went to get breakfast, they had no more food!
What made Josephe89 think that the hotel would be nicer?

User: MartaTravelz
May 27th, 2017

The staff at the hostel were very friendly and welcoming. The hostel only took cash payments, but they were helpful and let us drop our bags before going into town to find an ATM. The condition of our room left much to be desired, and the hostel overall was very different from the pictures. All that said, the price was good for the area and we were only a 10-15 minute walk from the beach. The hostel is popular with backpackers, and was a bit noisy at night because of this. To be fair, staff were always present and there to help when the noise level was too loud. The breakfast was ok, nothing special. All in all, the value of the hostel is great, but if you're looking for the usual hotel comforts then this place is not for you.
What did MartaTravelz think of her stay?
Select the things that were good according to the text.
The staff at the hostel were very friendly and welcoming.
The word "staff" in this sentence is talking about more than one person.
"Staff" is a group of people, and is usually plural. An individual would be "a member of staff".
All that said, the price was good for the area and we were only a 10-15 minute walk from the beach.
All in all, the value of the hostel is great, but if you're looking for the usual hotel comforts then this place is not for you.

There are two useful phrases based on the word "all" used in this text. "All that said," is a useful way to transition from a negative tone to a positive one. "All in all," is a nice way to begin a summary at the end of a review.
All in all, the value of the hostel is great, but if you're looking for the usual hotel comforts then this place is not for you.
In this sentence, MartaTravelz summarises her stay at the hostel.
"All in all" indicates that this sentence is a summary of what she said earlier.

User: Cool_HM
October 24th, 2018

Minh’s place was better than we thought possible. The pictures don’t do it justice! The house’s interior feels very luxurious, and there is a jaw-dropping view from the pool. We were very surprised when we arrived at how nice the house was! Minh was a super host. We went swimming every day and explored the city with Minh’s helpful suggestions for where to eat and what to see. On our first day she showed us around and gave us great tips on what to do. She also picked us up at the airport and led us from the villa to the nearby shops and restaurants. The pictures doesn’t show how private the villa is, we didn’t hear anyone and felt like we had the mountain all for ourselves. She was a very helpful host, and turned a romantic getaway into a once-in-a-lifetime unforgettable experience. If you're in Da Nang, don't hesitate to stay here, it will be the highlight of your trip! Thank you Minh for an amazing stay!
What did Cool_HM think of their stay?
Match the two parts of these phrases
What was most surprising about the stay?

The three texts in this lesson show a normal pattern for reviews. Usually negative reviews are short and just list problems, and usually people who write positive reviews like to add more detail. This is not a perfect rule, but it can be a helpful place to start.

If you need to write something in English, it can be helpful to look at a few examples to understand the patterns people follow to help you find the right style to use.
Based on these texts, match the review type to the style they follow.
This review uses shorter sentences and lists a series of problems.
This review uses linking words to balance positives with negatives.
This review uses more descriptive language like adjectives, and tells a story.
Try it yourself! Think of a recent trip (or invent one) and write a short review for the place you stayed.
It was..., We were very..., absolutely..., jaw-dropping, do not hestitate to...
